title: 111_hr294
content: The Act titled "Veteran-Owned Small Business Promotion Act of 2009" reauthorizes and improves the Department of Veterans Affairs Small Business Loan Program. The "Veteran-Owned Small Business Promotion Act of 2009" reauthorizes and amends Chapter 37 of title 38, United States Code. It includes the removal of section 3751, a clerical amendment to the table of sections, and a conforming amendment to section 3749. Additionally, the eligibility for small business loans is expanded by changing the definition of a "disabled veteran" and reducing the required percentage from 30% to 10%. The "Veteran-Owned Small Business Promotion Act of 2009" amends Chapter 37 of title 38, United States Code by removing section 3751 and making changes to section 3742. This includes revising the definition of a "disabled veteran" for small business loans and eliminating the authority to make direct loans. The "Veteran-Owned Small Business Promotion Act of 2009" amends Chapter 37 of title 38, United States Code by redesignating paragraphs and striking certain language in subsections (c), (d), and (e). The "Veteran-Owned Small Business Promotion Act of 2009" amends Chapter 37 of title 38, United States Code by redesignating paragraphs and striking certain language in subsections related to loan obligations. This includes removing references to suspending obligations and direct loans under the subchapter. The "Veteran-Owned Small Business Promotion Act of 2009" amends Chapter 37 of title 38, United States Code by redesignating paragraphs and striking certain language in subsections related to loan obligations. This includes removing references to suspending obligations and direct loans under the subchapter. Additionally, the maximum guaranty amount is increased from $200,000 to $500,000, and the Secretary is authorized to enter into contracts. The Secretary is authorized to enter into a contract for the program. The Secretary may subsidize interest rates of guaranteed loans by up to one-half of one percent for veterans' small business concerns. Preference is given to members of the National Guard and Reserves activated in support of the Global War on Terrorism. The authorization of appropriations for veterans' small business concerns is increased to $1,000,000,000 annually. SEC. 3. LIMITATION ON SMALL BUSINESS CONCERNS OWNED AND CONTROLLED BY VETERANS TO FURNISH BONDS. Sec. 8129 of title 38, United States Code, limits the requirement for performance or payment bonds for contracts with small business concerns owned and controlled by veterans to not exceed 50 percent of the contract amount. Subcontractors who are also small business concerns owned and controlled by veterans are similarly limited in bond requirements. The requirement for performance or payment bonds for contracts with small business concerns owned and controlled by veterans is limited to not exceed 50 percent of the contract amount. Prime contractors entering into a contract with the Secretary may provide a bond on behalf of a subcontractor meeting the definition of a small business concern owned and controlled by veterans. Small business concerns owned and controlled by veterans may be evaluated for bids and awarded contracts on the same basis as socially and economically disadvantaged small business concerns. The requirement for performance or payment bonds for these contracts is limited to not exceed 50 percent of the contract amount. Prime contractors can provide bonds on behalf of subcontractors meeting the veteran-owned small business criteria.
